aerial_conversion package

Submodules

aerial_conversion.coco module

A collectio of functions and structures for reading, writing, and creating coco annotations.

aerial_conversion.coco.coco_annotation_per_image(coco_json: str, tile_search_margin: int = 5)[source]

Function to get a list of annotations per image. This function is necessary in order to get the tile name from the COCO JSON file, as a reference for spatial coordinate conversion.

Parameters:

  • coco_json (str) – Path to COCO JSON file

  • tile_search_margin (int, optional) – Percentage of tile size to use as a search margin for finding overlapping polygons while joining raster. Defaults to 5 percent.

Returns:

List of annotations per image

Return type:

annotations_per_image (list)

aerial_conversion.coco.coco_annotation_per_image_df(coco_json: str, tile_search_margin: int = 10)[source]

Function to get a list of annotations per image. This function is necessary in order to get the tile name from the COCO JSON file, as a reference for spatial coordinate conversion.

Parameters:

  • coco_json (str) – Path to COCO JSON file

  • tile_search_margin (int, optional) – Percentage of tile size to use as a search margin for finding overlapping polygons while joining raster. Defaults to 10.

Returns:

Data frame of annotations with images image

Return type:

annotations_per_image (pd.DataFrame)

aerial_conversion.coco.coco_bbox(polygon)[source]

Generate a COCO format bounding box from a Polygon.

Based on code from: #https://www.immersivelimit.com/tutorials/create-coco-annotations-from-scratch/#coco-dataset-format

Parameters:

polygon (Polygon) – Polygon object

Returns:

COCO format bounding box

Return type:

cc_bbox (list)

aerial_conversion.coco.coco_image_annotations(raster_file_list, colour)[source]

Function to convert a list of rasters to a list of COCO image objects.

Parameters:

  • colour (bool, optional) – If True, save image in colour.

Returns:

coco_images object

Return type:

images (coco_images)

aerial_conversion.coco.coco_polygon_annotation(pixel_polygon: list, image_id, annot_id, class_id)[source]

Function to convert a polygon to a COCO annotation object.

Parameters:

  • pixel_polygon (list) – List of pixel coordinates generated via coordinates.spatial_polygon_to_pixel_rio()

  • image_id (int) – ID of image

  • annot_id (int) – ID of annotation

  • class_id (int) – ID of class

Returns:

COCO annotation object

Return type:

annot (dict)

aerial_conversion.coco.make_category(class_name: str, class_id: int, supercategory: str = 'landuse', trim=0)[source]

Function to build an individual COCO category.

Parameters:

  • class_name (str) – Name of class

  • class_id (int) – ID of class

  • supercategory (str, optional) – Supercategory of class. Defaults to “landuse”.

  • trim (int, optional) – Number of characters to trim from class name. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

COCO category object

Return type:

category (dict)

aerial_conversion.coco.make_category_object(geojson: GeoDataFrame, class_column: str, trim: int, supercategory_default: str = 'landuse')[source]

Function to build a COCO categories object.

Parameters:

  • geojson (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – GeoDataFrame containing class data

  • class_column (str) – Name of column containing class names

  • trim (int) – Number of characters to trim from class name

  • supercategory_default (str, optional) – Default supercategory of classes. Defaults to “landuse”.

Returns:

List of COCO category objects

Return type:

categories_json (list)

aerial_conversion.coco.polygon_prep(polygon, simplify_tolerance: float = 0.0, minimum_rotated_rectangle: bool = False)[source]

Prepares a polygon for export.

Parameters:

  • polygon (list) – A list of coordinates

  • simplify_tolerance (float, optional) – Tolerance for simplifying polygons. Accepts values between 0.0 and 1.0. Defaults to 0.0. If simplify_tolerance > 0, will simplify the polygon, without minimum rotated rectangle.

  • minimum_rotated_rectangle (bool, optional) – If true, will return the minimum rotated rectangle of the polygon. Defaults to False. If simplify_tolerance > 0, will simplify the polygon without minimum rotated rectangle.

Returns:

A list of coordinates

Return type:

polygon (list)

aerial_conversion.coco.raster_to_coco(raster_path: str, index: int, extension: str = 'png', bands: int = 3, colour: bool = True)[source]

Function to convert a raster to a COCO image object.

Parameters:

  • raster_path (str) – Path to raster

  • index (int) – Index of raster

  • extension (str, optional) – Extension of image. Defaults to “png”.

  • bands (int) – The number of bands to save. Default is 3 (for R-G-B).

  • colour (bool, optional) – If True, save image in colour. Defaults to True.

Returns:

COCO image object

Return type:

image (coco_image)

aerial_conversion.coordinates module

aerial_conversion.coordinates.get_tile_polygons(raster_tile: str, geojson: GeoDataFrame, filter: int = 0)[source]

Create polygons from a geosjon for an individual raster tile.

Parameters:

  • raster_tile – (str) a file name referring to the raster tile to be loaded

  • geojson – (gpd.GeoDataFrame) a geodataframe with polygons

  • filter – (int) an integer to filter out polygons with area less than the filter value

Returns:

geodataframe with polygons within the raster’s extent

Return type:

tile_polygon

aerial_conversion.coordinates.pixel_bbox_to_spatial_rio(geotiff, bbox)[source]

Converts pixel bbox to spatial bbox using rasterio.

Parameters:

  • geotiff (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object for reference

  • bbox (list) – List of pixel coordinates defining the bbox in coco bbox format

Returns:

List of spatial coordinates defining the bbox

Return type:

converted_coords (list)

aerial_conversion.coordinates.pixel_polygons_for_raster_tiles(raster_file_list: list, geojson: GeoDataFrame, verbose=1)[source]

  • geojson (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – GeoDataFrame containing polygons

  • verbose (int) – Verbosity level

Returns:

DataFrame containing pixel polygons

Return type:

pixel_df (pd.DataFrame)

aerial_conversion.coordinates.pixel_segmentation_to_spatial_rio(geotiff, segmentation)[source]

Converts pixel segmentation to spatial segmentation using rasterio.

Parameters:

  • geotiff (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object for reference

  • segmentation (list) – List of pixel coordinates defining the polygon in coco segmentation format

Returns:

List of spatial coordinates defining the polygon

Return type:

converted_coords (list)

aerial_conversion.coordinates.pixel_to_spatial_rio(geotiff, row_index, col_index)[source]

Converts pixel coordinates to spatial coordinates using rasterio. More information here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52443906/pixel-array- position-to-lat-long-gdal-python.

Parameters:

  • geotiff (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object (do not read, just open via rasterio.open(raster_path))

  • row_index (int) – pixel row

  • col_index (int) – pixel column

Returns:

(x,y) spatial coordinates

Return type:

tuple

  • dst_crs (str) – Destination coordinate system

  • coords (list) – List of coordinates to reproject

  • polygon (shapely.geometry.Polygon) – Polygon in spatial coordinates

Returns:

List of pixel coordinates defining the polygon

Return type:

converted_coords (list)

aerial_conversion.coordinates.spatial_to_pixel_rio(geotiff, x, y)[source]

Converts spatial coordinates to pixel coordinates using rasterio.

Parameters:

  • geotiff (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object

  • x (float) – longitudinal coordinate in spatial units

  • y (float) – latitudinal coordinate in spatial units

Returns:

(row_index,col_index) pixel coordinates

Return type:

tuple

aerial_conversion.tiles module

aerial_conversion.tiles.get_tiles(geotiff: DatasetReader, tile_width: int = 2000, tile_height: int = 2000, map_units: bool = False, offset: float = 0.0)[source]

Defines a set of tiles over a raster layer based on user specified dimensions.

Parameters:

  • raster (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object

  • tile_width (int, optional) – Width of tile. Defaults to 2000.

  • tile_height (int, optional) – Height of tile. Defaults to 2000.

  • map_units (bool, optional) – If True, tile_width and tile_height are in map units. Defaults to False.

  • offset (float, optional) – Padding/offset/overlap in percentage of tile. Defaults to 0.0.

Yields:

window (rio.windows.Window) – Rasterio window object transform (Affine): Rasterio affine transform object

aerial_conversion.tiles.get_tiles_list_from_dir(tiles_dir: str, extension: str = 'tif')[source]

Get a list of tiles from a directory.

Parameters:

  • tiles_dir (str) – Path to tiles directory.

  • extension (str, optional) – Extension of tiles. Defaults to “tif”.

Returns:

List of tiles.

Return type:

tiles_list (list)

aerial_conversion.tiles.save_tiles(geotiff: DatasetReader, out_path: str, tile_size: int = 2000, tile_template: str = 'tile_{}-{}.tif', offset: float = 0.0)[source]

Save tiles from a raster file.

Parameters:

  • raster (rio.DatasetReader) – Rasterio raster object

  • out_path (str) – Path to save tiles to.

  • tile_size (int) – Size of tiles.

  • tile_template (str) – Template for tile names. Should contain two {} placeholders for the x and y coordinates of the tile.

  • offset (float, optional) – Padding/offset/overlap in percentage of tile. Defaults to 0.0.

Returns:

None

aerial_conversion.tiles.tile_neighbourhood_list(tiles: list) → dict[source]

Get a dictionary of tile neighbourhoods.

Using the naming schema of tiles, find the neighbouring tiles for each tile, and store them in a dictionary.

It is important to check if the tile names are in the following format: “tile_{}-{}.tif”, where the {} are the x and y coordinates of the tile.

Parameters:

tiles (list) – List of rasterio raster objects.

Returns:

Dictionary of tile neighbourhoods.

Return type:

neighbourhood_dict (dict)

aerial_conversion.COCO_validator module

This module is currently not used in the main code. It is a work in progress.
